title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the Medicinal Products (Safety
text_raw:
1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the Medicinal Products (Safety 

Features on Packaging) Regulations 2022. 

(2) The Regulations of 2019 and these Regulations may be cited together 
as the Medicinal Products (Safety Features on Packaging) Regulations 2019 
and 2022. 

Interpretation
text_norm: 1 (1) regulation may cited medicinal product (safety feature packaging) regulation 2022 (2) regulation 2019 regulation may cited together medicinal product (safety feature packaging) regulation 2019 2022 interpretation

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 2. (1) In these Regulations—
text_raw:
2. (1) In these Regulations— 

“Authority” means the Health Products Regulatory Authority; 

“Directive” means Directive 2001/83/EC of the European Parliament and of 
the Council of 6 November 20014, as amended from time to time; 

“EU Regulation” means Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/161 of 
2 October 20151, as amended by Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 
2021/1686 of 7 July 20212 and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 
2022/315 of 17 December 20213; 

“health centre” means a health centre under the management or control of a 
hospital; 

“healthcare institution” means a hospital, in- or outpatient clinic or health 
centre; 

 “hub” means the central information and data router of the repositories system 
referred to in Article 32 of the EU Regulation; 

1 OJ No. L 32, 9.2.2016, p. 1. 
2 OJ No. L 332, 21.9.2021, p. 1. 
3 OJ No. L 55, 28.2.2022, p. 33. 
4 OJ No. L 311, 28.11.2001, p. 67. 

Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
“Iris Oifigiúil” of 3rd June, 2022. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 [270] 3 

“in- or outpatient clinic” means an in- or outpatient, or day patient, clinic under 
the management or control of a hospital; 

“manufacturer” means the holder of a manufacturer’s authorisation, as defined 
in Regulation 3(1) of the Medicinal Products (Control of Manufacture) 
Regulations 2007 (S.I. No. 539 of 2007); 

“marketing authorisation holder” means 
the holder of a marketing 
authorisation, as defined in Regulation 3(1) of the Medicinal Products (Control 
of Placing on the Market) Regulations 2007 (S.I. No. 540 of 2007); 

“packaging” means outer packaging or, in the case of a medicinal product with 
no outer packaging, the immediate packaging; 

“Regulations of 2019” means the Medicinal Products (Safety Features on 
Packaging) Regulations 2019 (S.I. No. 36 of 2019); 

“repositories system” means the system to be set up and managed under 
Chapter VII of the EU Regulation; 

“safety features” means the unique identifier and anti-tampering device 
required to be placed on the packaging of medicinal products under the EU 
Regulation; 

“Society” means the Pharmaceutical Society of Ireland; 

“wholesaler” means the holder of a wholesaler’s authorisation, as defined in 
Regulation 4(1) of the Medicinal Products (Control of Wholesale Distribution) 
Regulations 2007 (S.I. No. 538 of 2007) and, for the avoidance of doubt, does 
not include a pharmacist supplying medicinal products pursuant to Regulation 
6(c) of those Regulations. 

(2) A word or expression that is used in these Regulations and is also used 
in the EU Regulation or the Directive has, unless the context otherwise 
requires, the same meaning in these Regulations that it has in the EU 
Regulation or the Directive. 

Scope

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 3. These Regulations apply to—
text_raw:
3. These Regulations apply to— 

(a) medicinal products subject to prescription other than those listed 

in Annex I to the EU Regulation, and 

(b) medicinal products which are not subject to prescription and are 

listed in Annex II to the EU Regulation. 

PART 2 

OFFENCES – GENERAL 

Placing of unique identifier on packaging
text_norm: 3 regulation apply to-- (a) medicinal product subject prescription listed annex eu regulation (b) medicinal product subject prescription listed annex ii eu regulation part 2 offence - general placing unique identifier packaging

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 4. A person who places on the market a medicinal product which does not
text_raw:
4. A person who places on the market a medicinal product which does not 

have a unique identifier placed on its packaging is guilty of an offence. 

 
 
 
 
 4 [270] 

Composition of unique identifier
text_norm: 4 person place market medicinal product unique identifier placed packaging guilty offence 4 270 composition unique identifier

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 5. A person who places on the market a medicinal product with a unique
text_raw:
5. A person who places on the market a medicinal product with a unique 
identifier which fails to comply with the technical specifications set out in 
Article 4 of the EU Regulation is guilty of an offence. 

Carrier of unique identifier
text_norm: 5 person place market medicinal product unique identifier fails comply technical specification set article 4 eu regulation guilty offence carrier unique identifier

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 6. A person who places on the market a medicinal product with a unique
text_raw:
6. A person who places on the market a medicinal product with a unique 
identifier encoded otherwise than in accordance with Article 5 of the EU 
Regulation is guilty of an offence. 

Quality of printing of unique identifier
text_norm: 6 person place market medicinal product unique identifier encoded otherwise accordance article 5 eu regulation guilty offence quality printing unique identifier

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 7. A person who places on the market a medicinal product with a unique
text_raw:
7. A person who places on the market a medicinal product with a unique 
identifier which does not comply with the quality of printing requirements set 
out in Article 6 of the EU Regulation is guilty of an offence. 

Human-readable elements of unique identifier
text_norm: 7 person place market medicinal product unique identifier comply quality printing requirement set article 6 eu regulation guilty offence human-readable element unique identifier

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 8. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person who places on the market a
text_raw:
8. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person who places on the market a 
medicinal product which does not have the data elements listed in Article 7(1) 
of the EU Regulation (other than subparagraph (c) thereof) on its packaging in 
human-readable format is guilty of an offence. 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply where the sum of the two longest 

dimensions of the packaging equals or is less than 10 centimetres. 

(3) Subject to paragraph (4), a person who places on the market a medicinal 
product which does not have the human-readable data elements referred to in 
paragraph (1) adjacent to the two-dimensional barcode carrying the unique 
identifier is guilty of an offence. 

(4) Paragraph (3) shall not apply where the dimensions of the packaging of 
the medicinal product do not allow for the human-readable data elements to be 
adjacent to the two dimensional barcode. 

Other barcodes on packaging
text_norm: 8 (1) subject paragraph (2) person place market medicinal product data element listed article 7(1) eu regulation (other subparagraph (c) thereof) packaging human-readable format guilty offence (2) paragraph (1) shall apply sum two longest dimension packaging equal le 10 centimetre (3) subject paragraph (4) person place market medicinal product human-readable data element referred paragraph (1) adjacent two-dimensional barcode carrying unique identifier guilty offence (4) paragraph (3) shall apply dimension packaging medicinal product allow human-readable data element adjacent two dimensional barcode barcodes packaging

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 9. A person who places on the market a medicinal product which has on its
text_raw:
9. A person who places on the market a medicinal product which has on its 
packaging, for the purpose of identification and verification of authenticity, any 
visible two-dimensional barcode other than the two-dimensional barcode 
carrying the unique identifier, is guilty of an offence. 

Unique identifiers which have been decommissioned
text_norm: 9 person place market medicinal product packaging purpose identification verification authenticity visible two-dimensional barcode two-dimensional barcode carrying unique identifier guilty offence unique identifier decommissioned

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 10. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person who further distributes or supplies
text_raw:
10. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person who further distributes or supplies 
to the public a medicinal product bearing a unique identifier which has been 
decommissioned is guilty of an offence. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 [270] 5 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply where one of the exceptions listed in 

Article 12 of the EU Regulation applies. 

Reversing the status of decommissioned unique identifier

text_raw:
11. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person who reverses the status of a

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply where the conditions listed in Article 13(1) 

of the EU Regulation are fulfilled.

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 12. A person who places on the market a medicinal product and fails to
text_raw:
12. A person who places on the market a medicinal product and fails to 
comply with the record keeping requirements set out in Article 15 of the EU 
Regulation in respect of such medicinal product is guilty of an offence. 

PART 3 

OFFENCES BY MANUFACTURERS 

Verifications before removing or replacing safety features
text_norm: 12 person place market medicinal product fails comply record keeping requirement set article 15 eu regulation respect medicinal product guilty offence part 3 offence manufacturer verification removing replacing safety feature

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 13. A manufacturer who fails to perform verifications required under Articles
text_raw:
13. A manufacturer who fails to perform verifications required under Articles 
16 and 17 of the EU Regulation before removing, covering (either fully or 
partially) or replacing safety features is guilty of an offence. 

Actions to be taken by manufacturers in case of tampering or suspected 
falsification
text_norm: 13 manufacturer fails perform verification required article 16 17 eu regulation removing covering (either fully partially) replacing safety feature guilty offence action taken manufacturer case tampering suspected falsification

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 14. (1) Where a manufacturer has reason to believe that—
text_raw:
14. (1) Where a manufacturer has reason to believe that— 

(a) 

(b) 

the packaging of a medicinal product has been tampered with, or 

the verification of the safety features on a medicinal product 
indicates that the product may not be authentic, 

the manufacturer is guilty of an offence if he or she— 

(i) 

(ii) 

places the medicinal product on the market, or 

fails to immediately inform the Authority after forming such 
belief. 

PART 4 

OFFENCES BY WHOLESALERS 

Verification of authenticity of unique identifier
text_norm: 14 (1) manufacturer reason believe that-- (a) (b) packaging medicinal product tampered verification safety feature medicinal product indicates product may authentic manufacturer guilty offence she-- (i) (ii) place medicinal product market fails immediately inform authority forming belief part 4 offence wholesaler verification authenticity unique identifier

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 15. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a wholesaler in physical possession of a
text_raw:
15. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a wholesaler in physical possession of a 
medicinal product referred to in Article 20(a) or (b) of the EU Regulation who 
fails to verify the authenticity of the unique identifier on the product is guilty of 
an offence. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 6 [270] 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply in the case of a medicinal product referred 
to in Article 20(b) of the EU Regulation in any of the situations listed in Article 
21 of the EU Regulation. 

Decommissioning of unique identifiers

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 16. A wholesaler in physical possession of a medicinal product referred to in
text_raw:
16. A wholesaler in physical possession of a medicinal product referred to in 
Article 22 of the EU Regulation who fails to verify the authenticity of, and 
decommission, the unique identifier of the product is guilty of an offence. 

Verifications of medicinal products for United Kingdom market
text_norm: 16 wholesaler physical possession medicinal product referred article 22 eu regulation fails verify authenticity decommission unique identifier product guilty offence verification medicinal product united kingdom market

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 17. In the case of a shipment of medicinal products manufactured and
text_raw:
17. In the case of a shipment of medicinal products manufactured and 
labelled for the United Kingdom market, a wholesaler who fails to perform 
adequate verifications to ensure that the shipment complies with the 
requirement to bear safety features under Article 54a(1) of Directive 
2001/83/EC when received from— 

(a) 

(b) 

(c) 

the manufacturer, 

the marketing authorisation holder, or 

a wholesaler who is designated by the marketing authorisation 
holder, by means of a written contract, to store and distribute the 
products covered by his marketing authorisation on his behalf, 

is guilty of an offence. 

Actions to be taken in case of tampering or suspected falsification

18. (1) Where a wholesaler has reason to believe that—

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 19. A wholesaler who fails to comply with Regulation 5(2) of the
text_raw:
19. A wholesaler who fails to comply with Regulation 5(2) of the

 [270] 7 

PART 5 

OFFENCES BY PERSONS AUTHORISED TO SUPPLY MEDICINAL 
PRODUCTS TO THE PUBLIC 

Verification and decommissioning
text_norm: 19 wholesaler fails comply regulation 5(2) regulation 2019 applicable guilty offence 270 7 part 5 offence person authorised supply medicinal product public verification decommissioning

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 20. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person authorised to supply medicinal
text_raw:
20. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a person authorised to supply medicinal 
products to the public who fails to verify the safety features and decommission 
the unique identifier of any medicinal product bearing safety features, in 
accordance with Article 25(3) of the EU Regulation— 

(a) before supplying that product to the public, 

(b) 

(c) 

(d) 

(e) 

in the case of a person operating within a healthcare institution, 
between the delivery of the product to the healthcare institution 
and the sale or supplying of it to the public, 

in the case of a medicinal product that cannot be returned to the 
wholesaler or manufacturer, while the product is in his or her 
physical possession, 

in the case of a medicinal product that is requested as a sample 
by the Authority or the Society, prior to providing such sample, 

in the case of a medicinal product that he or she supplies for 
subsequent use as authorised investigational medicinal products 
or authorised auxiliary medicinal products as defined in Article 
2(2)(9) and (10) of Regulation (EU) No. 536/2014 of the 
European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 20145, at 
the time of such supply, 

(f) 

in the case of the supply of only part of a pack of a medicinal 
product the unique identifier of which is not decommissioned, 
when the pack is opened for the first time, or 

(g) where there are technical problems preventing verification and 

decommissioning, as soon as those problems are solved, 

is guilty of an offence. 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply— 

(a) 

in the case of a medicinal product provided, to a person 
authorised or entitled to supply medicinal products to the public, 
as a free sample in accordance with Article 96 of the Directive, 
and 

(b) where the obligation to verify and decommission is on the 

wholesaler pursuant to Article 5(2) of the Regulations of 2019. 

(3) Where paragraph (2)(b) applies, a person authorised to supply medicinal 
products to the public who fails to verify the authenticity of the anti-tampering 
device at the time the medicinal product is supplied to the public is guilty of an 
offence. 

5 OJ No. L 158, 27.5.2014, p. 1. 

 
 
 
 
 8 [270] 

Actions to be taken in case of tampering or suspected falsification

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 21. (1) Where a person authorised to supply medicinal products to the public
text_raw:
21. (1) Where a person authorised to supply medicinal products to the public 

has reason to believe that— 

(a) 

(b) 

the packaging of a medicinal product has been tampered with, or 

the verification of the safety features on a medicinal product 
indicates that the product may not be authentic, 

the person is guilty of an offence if he or she— 

(i) 

supplies the medicinal product, or 

(ii) 

fails to immediately inform the Authority after forming such 
belief. 

PART 6 

OFFENCES BY MARKETING AUTHORISATION HOLDERS, PARALLEL 
IMPORTERS AND PARALLEL DISTRIBUTORS 

Uploading of information in repositories system
text_norm: 21 (1) person authorised supply medicinal product public reason believe that-- (a) (b) packaging medicinal product tampered verification safety feature medicinal product indicates product may authentic person guilty offence she-- (i) supply medicinal product (ii) fails immediately inform authority forming belief part 6 offence marketing authorisation holder parallel importer parallel distributor uploading information repository system

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 22. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a marketing authorisation holder who fails
text_raw:
22. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a marketing authorisation holder who fails 

to— 

(a) upload the information referred to in Article 33(2) of the EU 
Regulation to the repositories system, in the manner required 
under Article 33(3) of the EU Regulation, before releasing the 
medicinal product for sale or distribution by the manufacturer, 
or 

(b) keep such information up to date thereafter, 

is guilty of an offence. 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply in the case of parallel imported or parallel 
distributed medicinal products bearing an equivalent unique identifier for the 
purposes of complying with Article 47a of the Directive. 

(3) In the case of parallel imported or parallel distributed medicinal products 
bearing an equivalent unique identifier for the purposes of complying with 
Article 47a of the Directive, if the person responsible for placing the products 
on the market fails to— 

(a) upload the information referred to in Article 33(2) of the EU 
Regulation to the repositories system, in the manner required 
under Article 33(3) of the EU Regulation, before releasing the 
medicinal product for sale or distribution by the manufacturer, 
or 

(b) keep such information up to date thereafter, 

that person is guilty of an offence. 

 
 
 
 
 [270] 9 

Repackaged or relabelled packs
text_norm: 22 (1) subject paragraph (2) marketing authorisation holder fails to-- (a) upload information referred article 33(2) eu regulation repository system manner required article 33(3) eu regulation releasing medicinal product sale distribution manufacturer (b) keep information date thereafter guilty offence (2) paragraph (1) shall apply case parallel imported parallel distributed medicinal product bearing equivalent unique identifier purpose complying article 47a directive (3) case parallel imported parallel distributed medicinal product bearing equivalent unique identifier purpose complying article 47a directive person responsible placing product market fails to-- (a) upload information referred article 33(2) eu regulation repository system manner required article 33(3) eu regulation releasing medicinal product sale distribution manufacturer (b) keep information date thereafter person guilty offence 270 9 repackaged relabelled pack

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 23. For each batch of repackaged or relabelled packs of a medicinal product
text_raw:
23. For each batch of repackaged or relabelled packs of a medicinal product 
on which equivalent unique identifiers were placed for the purposes of 
complying with Article 47a of the Directive, the person responsible for placing 
the medicinal product on the market is guilty of an offence if he or she fails to 
upload to the hub— 

(a) 

(b) 

the batch number or numbers of the packs which are to be 
repackaged or relabelled and of the unique identifiers on those 
packs, or 

the batch number of the batch resulting from the repackaging or 
relabelling operations and the equivalent unique identifiers in 
that batch. 

Products recalled, withdrawn or stolen
text_norm: 23 batch repackaged relabelled pack medicinal product equivalent unique identifier placed purpose complying article 47a directive person responsible placing medicinal product market guilty offence fails upload hub-- (a) (b) batch number number pack repackaged relabelled unique identifier pack batch number batch resulting repackaging relabelling operation equivalent unique identifier batch product recalled withdrawn stolen

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 24. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), where a medicinal product is recalled,
text_raw:
24. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), where a medicinal product is recalled, 
withdrawn or stolen, and the marketing authorisation holder fails to take the 
measures set out in Article 40 of the EU Regulation, the marketing 
authorisation holder is guilty of an offence. 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply in the case of parallel imported or parallel 
distributed medicinal products bearing an equivalent unique identifier for the 
purposes of complying with Article 47a of the Directive. 

(3) In the case of parallel imported or parallel distributed medicinal products 
bearing an equivalent unique identifier for the purposes of complying with 
Article 47a of the Directive, where a medicinal product is recalled, withdrawn 
or stolen, and the person responsible for placing the product on the market fails 
to take the measures set out in Article 40 of the EU Regulation, that person is 
guilty of an offence. 

Products to be supplied as free samples
text_norm: 24 (1) subject paragraph (2) medicinal product recalled withdrawn stolen marketing authorisation holder fails take measure set article 40 eu regulation marketing authorisation holder guilty offence (2) paragraph (1) shall apply case parallel imported parallel distributed medicinal product bearing equivalent unique identifier purpose complying article 47a directive (3) case parallel imported parallel distributed medicinal product bearing equivalent unique identifier purpose complying article 47a directive medicinal product recalled withdrawn stolen person responsible placing product market fails take measure set article 40 eu regulation person guilty offence product supplied free sample

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 25. A marketing authorisation holder intending to supply a medicinal
text_raw:
25. A marketing authorisation holder intending to supply a medicinal 
product as a free sample in accordance with Article 96 of the Directive, where 
that product bears the safety features, who fails to— 

(a) 

(b) 

indicate it as a free sample in the repositories system, and 

ensure the decommissioning of its unique identifier before 
providing it to the persons qualified to prescribe it, 

is guilty of an offence. 

Removal of unique identifiers from repositories system
text_norm: 25 marketing authorisation holder intending supply medicinal product free sample accordance article 96 directive product bear safety feature fails to-- (a) (b) indicate free sample repository system ensure decommissioning unique identifier providing person qualified prescribe guilty offence removal unique identifier repository system

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 26. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a marketing authorisation holder who
text_raw:
26. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a marketing authorisation holder who 
uploads unique identifiers in the repositories system before having removed 
from therein older unique identifiers containing the same product code and 
serial number as the unique identifiers being uploaded is guilty of an offence. 

 
 
 
 
 10 [270] 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply in the case of parallel imported or parallel 
distributed medicinal products bearing an equivalent unique identifier for the 
purposes of complying with Article 47a of the Directive. 

(3) In the case of parallel imported or parallel distributed medicinal products 
bearing an equivalent unique identifier for the purposes of complying with 
Article 47a of the Directive, where the person responsible for placing those 
medicinal products on the market uploads unique identifiers in the repositories 
system before having removed from therein older unique identifiers containing 
the same product code and serial number as the unique identifiers being 
uploaded, that person is guilty of an offence. 

PART 7 

OFFENCES BY ENTITIES MANAGING REPOSITORIES 

Obligations of legal entities establishing and managing repository in State

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 27. A legal entity managing a repository in the State, as part of the
text_raw:
27. A legal entity managing a repository in the State, as part of the 
repositories system, which fails to perform any of the actions listed in Article 
37 of the EU Regulation is guilty of an offence. 

Data protection and data ownership
text_norm: 27 legal entity managing repository state part repository system fails perform action listed article 37 eu regulation guilty offence data protection data ownership

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 28. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a legal entity managing a repository in the
text_raw:
28. (1) Subject to paragraph (2), a legal entity managing a repository in the 
State, as part of the repositories system, which accesses an audit trail (as 
referred to in Article 35(1)(g) of the EU Regulation) and the data contained 
therein without the written agreement of the legitimate data owners, as 
designated by Article 38(1) of the EU Regulation, is guilty of an offence. 

(2) Paragraph (1) shall not apply in the case of access for the purpose of 
investigating potential incidents of falsification flagged in the system in 
accordance with Article 36(b) of the EU Regulation. 

Access by Authority

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 29. A legal entity managing a repository used to verify the authenticity of or
text_raw:
29. A legal entity managing a repository used to verify the authenticity of or 
decommission the unique identifiers of medicinal products placed on the 
market in the State, as part of the repositories system, which refuses to grant 
the Authority access to that repository and the information contained therein 
for one of the purposes listed in Article 39 of the EU Regulation is guilty of an 
offence. 

PART 8 

TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS 

Transitional provisions
text_norm: 29 legal entity managing repository used verify authenticity decommission unique identifier medicinal product placed market state part repository system refuse grant authority access repository information contained therein one purpose listed article 39 eu regulation guilty offence part 8 transitional provision transitional provision

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: 30. (1) A person is not guilty of an offence under these Regulations where
text_raw:
30. (1) A person is not guilty of an offence under these Regulations where 
he or she distributes or supplies to the public a medicinal product that had been 
placed on the market without the safety features in the State before the coming 

 
 
 
 
 
 [270] 11

into operation of these Regulations, provided the medicinal product is not 
repackaged or relabelled thereafter, until the expiry date of the medicinal 
product. 

(2) Notwithstanding Regulation 17, until 31 December 2024 a wholesaler is
not guilty of an offence for failure to verify the authenticity of and 
decommission the unique identifier of a medicinal product referred to in 
Article 22(a) of the EU Regulation where the medicinal product is 
manufactured and labelled for the United Kingdom market or for the United 
Kingdom market and the markets of Cyprus, Malta or the State, and which the 
wholesaler intends to distribute in the United Kingdom. 

GIVEN under my Official Seal, 

1 June, 2022. 

STEPHEN DONNELLY, 
Minister for Health. 

 12 [270]

title: Irish Medicines Board Act 1995 (No. 29 of 1995) and for the purpose of giving
heading: (This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a
text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a 
legal interpretation.) 

The purpose of these Regulations is to introduce offences for breaches 
of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/16 of 2 October 2015 
and related offences. 

These Regulations may be cited as the Medicinal Products (Safety Features 
on Packaging) Regulations 2022. 

 [270] 13
